titleStmt.title: To the worshipful our good benefactor.

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: To the worshipful our good benefactor.

monogr.title: To the worshipful our good benefactor : In all lamentable manner, most humbly beseecheth your good worship, wee the miserable multitude of very poore distressed prisoners, in the hole of Woodstreet Counter, in nomber fifite poore men, or thereabouts, ying vpon the bare boordes, still languishing in great neede

div.head: To the worshipful our good benefactor.
div.p:
IN all lamentable manner, most humbly beséecheth your good Worship, wée the miserable multitude of very poore distressed prisoners, in the hole of Woodstréet Counter, in nomber Fiftie poore men, or ther • abouts, ying vpon the bare boordes, still languishing in great neede, colde an • miserie, who, by reason of this daungerous and troublesome time, be almost •• mished and hunger starued to death: others very sore sicke and diseased fo •
•• nt of reliefe and sustenance, by reason of the great number which dayly incr •• seth, dooth in all humblenes, most humbly beséech your good Worship, euen for gods sake, to pitie our poore lamentable and distressed cases. And nowe •• l • e to relieue, and comfort vs with your christian and godly charitie against this holie and blessed time of Easter. And wee, according to our bounden duties, do, and will, dayly pray vnto Almighty God, for your long life, and happy prosperitie.
div.closer: We humbly pray, your christian and godly charitie to be sent vnto vs by some of your seruants.
